w3x1zjBObZMYleqcJGlnVg.text: We tried out the Bangkok jam in Singapura plaza, and it was good. Our two dishes were brought to us after just 10 minutes, as Well as our drinks. We took the vegi pad Thai and the vegi coconut sauce spaghetti. Both portions were not really large and the flavours of the spaghetti were so so. Our Tea's were at huge. We sar their for an hour just to finish our tea.

D55383XAXUUzAhJSZE_GqQ.text: Food here is at most average but the long waiting time is why they lost one star with me. We ordered:* Spaghetti with Prawn in Tomyam coconut sauce - I thought this kinda sound strange but there were more than 2 reviewers who mentioned it as good so I thought we'll try. My gut was right, the sauce was coconut-y and Tomyam-y but the concoction just doesn't kick it. Sad  * Olive Rice - after a long wait, we hungrily ate it up and liked it. * Mixed Grill - this was great. The chicken and beef slices were nicely charred with right amount of BBQ taste. The sotong was also done just nicely without making it into rubber. Unlikely to return as the wait doesn't warrant the taste of food.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Jam - Singapore, Singapore. Spaghetti with prawn in Tom yam coconut sauce

Fq3btnbXQ-G-ObY_qJC6Vw.text: A Steaming Pot of GoodnessBangkok Jam has been one of my preferred "commercial" Thai restaurants to visit but it's been a while since I was back. We happened to be looking around for dinner at Plaza Singapura when we stumbled upon their Steamboat Buffet! Being an avid fan of steamboats and having the Gf suddenly agreeable too (she's not a big fan of steamboat), I had to take the chance to give t a try and I had no regrets. Soup BaseUnlike other steamboat speciality restaurants, there isn't anything overly fancy about their soup based here. No laksa, collagen or magic dust, just a simple selection of chicken, pork, red Tom yum or clear Tom yum. We decided on the clear Tom yum since, according to them, was the less spicier option. It was a really good soup base. Fragrant, sour, sweet, without being overly spicy, it tasted like a really heart warming bowl on Tom yum soup, which was refreshing as compared to some other places that use Tom yum stock cubes. The Ingredients Don't expect an extremely wide variety of ingredients here too. There's enough to keep you satisfied but there isn't the usual suspects like hot dogs and luncheon meats and in terms of seafood, there's only the option of baby octopuses, Cuttlefish and Dory. The soup does come with 3 fairly large prawns though, which was a bit of a bonus. What they do have here may be limited but very good ingredients. The pork and beef were good and the beef and pork balls were good too. There's also the option of stick noodles (those used thai boat noodles) and glass noodles, which made the whole experience very thai. Plus PointsThe free flow drinks. They don't believe in charging you for soft drinks or water. Instead, they've included a free flow of ice lemon tea, lemongrass tea and the ever popular thai iced tea. They do have desserts available but that's at a separate charge though. OverallDefinitely worth the try. What they lack in quantity they certainly make up with quality and if you like yourself a nice boiling pot of good Tom yum than this it definitely your cup or pot of tea.

hKhVmQPChRhQdAFeE9NrMQ.text: Went in with low expectations as this place had received some harsh reviews. However, I​ was pleasantly surprised. I had a prawn PhatThai that​ was serviced in good time and certainly hit the spot for me. Was it earth​ shattering? No, but I will be happy to venture back though. My main​ gripe​ is the staff could smile more :)

wQYdIFFActvF3bgLeD_udw.text: The first time I patronised this chain, the food was really good.Inevitably, though, the curse of food in Singapore (especially for chains) hit and quality plummeted.The noodles I got were haphazardly fried and had no wok flavour at all. And the prawns had way too much sodium bicarbonate.This place is expensive too.Stay away at all costs!(the Caramel Thai Tea Blend was a pretty good ice blended version of Thai iced tea, but it hardly made up for the awful meal)

CDE9vGCw9FjhVOTRUjJurw.text: Service is bad! We waited for 30 mins before the food is served. And we had to approach the staffs twice just to get some water. And my friend and I asked for a plate and they only gave us a small plate (10cm diameter) and refused to give a normal size plate. According to the manager, the normal size plate only given if we order rice. Oh Gosh!! We just asked for an empty plate... The food was okay... But the service was really sucks ... I will NOT go there anymore.

E4tXsU3VNPncmEaWHUsSZg.text: My friend had a wriggling live worm on her basil pork rice. Server waived off her dish and offered to change mine as I had the beef.Not sure if the salad was too fresh that worms were on it or was it  a hygiene issue. The side dishes weren't too fanastic, the fish cakes seem to be made from paste and could have had more flavours.Overall, there's room for improvement.

xOzkYXgPZG5BOMqKZpIcjQ.text: I would NOT recommend Bangkok Jam. I came here with my friend and we both eat a lot so we decided to order three dishes between us. Each dish costs between $10-$18. The drinks are all about $5-$6 and dessert, (for example mango sticky rice) was about $9. The portions were really small and disappointing. We expected much larger portions for the price we paid. The food tasted good simply because Thai food is amazing but nothing special compared to other Thai restaurants in Singapore. The service wasn't particularly good either. In summary, Bangkok Jam is overpriced for what it is. The portions are small, the food is nothing special and the restaurant isn't high end. If you are looking for good Thai food, look elsewhere. You can order much more food or go to a higher end for the same price as dishes here. We ended up paying $30 each for 3 dishes to share with rice. We didn't even order drinks or dessert.

T-eAMLs6K_MORFRcP3dLSw.text: Okay, having had incredible Thai food in Bangkok 20 days ago I was missing it, and my Aunty suggested this place. Our usual Thai hangout is either Sabai, or Folks Collective, so that should give you an idea of our benchmark.Food was ok. How badly can you screw up a coconut curry and meat dish?It wasn't good value either. The portions were what you'd expect in Thailand, and the salt and oil were probably what you'd expect in Singapore! Too much!It's a decent effort, but half-hearted, and wasteful at best.The service was ok. Our mango salad was serves way too sour and the mango was too raw. My Aunty (who loves Thai food) couldn't even eat it, and we asked to change to another dish, and was not charged. Not bad, but that kind of thing seems the norm at this place. Subpar food with cheesy decor.I'd spend my money at Sabai and Folks Collective.....or cook Thai better anyday!Don't bother with this place.

SjpAO1srmszJK_sI5bUjpg.text: I didn't have too high expectations going to this place, but I was starving so ducked in. It was an average meal and alright for the price. I could easily see this being a joint I go to for a quick feed in Dhoby Ghaut. Oh and the other half (girlfriend) wanted me to mention there was a ton of garlic in our meals. Quite a bit too much! Overall alright food for a good price.

5zXntXzxKE-pDRQxDvFeKA.text: I'm about as badass as a napping puppy.  So coming into this restaurant and being seated at the edge of a balcony overlooking the other floors of Plaza Singapura, I had high expectations for my meal to be quite the thrilling experience.I mean, the name of this restaurant is called Bangkok Jam.  That sounds pretty intense, already.  And the decor is adorable: full of traffic signs, stoplights, telephone poles and wires, Metro/MRT maps, and street lamps.  Even before ordering, I was already starting to get an adrenaline rush after being reminded of the anxiety that is Los Angeles traffic.Now, I don't know why people have been complaining about poor service--it must have been early growing pains.  We were seated promptly, received our menus quickly, and were served drinks rather rapidly as well.  The staff was attentive, but not bothersome.  If anything, the staff and their service helped assuage any anxiety I was feeling from my fear of heights.  One of the people at a neighboring table even changed her order after picking at her food, and their server was still very accommodating.I had gone with my roommate, who ordered their seafood pad thai.  I ordered their egg noodle with bacon and crab pieces (didn't know that was a Thai dish o.O), which was marked as a special in their menu.  It seemed that we didn't receive a large portion for the amount we each paid (S$11.90), but upon mixing the noodles, the food seemed to expand and it looked like we were both going to be satiated as opposed to slightly-less-than-famished.Her dish had a hint of smoke, which tasted good, although not very Thai authentic.  She said she really enjoyed it, but had had better Thai food before.I, on the other hand, had no idea what a ride I was in for.While I agreed with my roommate that my dish didn't taste very Thai authentic, initial impressions had me puzzled as to what it actually did taste like:  It didn't taste like either crab or bacon, but rather, just egg noodles.  It did taste good, but wasn't too much different than any other fried noodles found at a Hawker center.  Where was the thrilling experience everything had been leading up to?Then, I spied a tiny cup with Thai chili oil and lime(?) juice that came with my noodles.  Feeling courageous (or badass, if you will), I poured it in and mixed my noodles thoroughly.  My roommate had a bite of mine and said it tasted good, so I got a huge forkful of noodles and eagerly shoved it in my mouth.And immediately screamed.Not loudly enough to make our neighbors turn, though.  They seemed to be thoroughly enjoying scarfing down their noodles and the changed order.My roommate looked at me, alarmed.  She knew I was a chronic victim of wasabi/chili overdose, and thought I had poured the spicy oil with a little too much gusto.  When she asked me what was wrong, I could barely answer.Not because the food was spicy.  But because I had accidentally eaten an ENTIRE raw garlic clove that had somehow stowed away in my bite of noodles.  And because I was, at the moment, quickly dying.I scarfed down my noodles to chase the garlic I had just ingested.  And then half a liter of water.  People must have thought this was the first meal I had eaten in a month, with the speed at which I was eating.  Unfortunately, since my taste buds had been sufficiently obliterated by that shocker of a first bite, I could only taste garlic afterwards.  I can only presume that the dish tasted better with the oil mixed in, since everything usually tastes better with more fat.  (Cue Paula Deen.)Bangkok Jam was definitely a... rigorous experience.  I just wish the chef would dice his aromatics more finely.  Now excuse me as I look for an army of vampires to slay with my breath.

QoMd6jqk6GE_6d3KpV7xhw.text: Exactly why does this place exist, and WHY is there a crowd? (I have figured out the answer to the latter, but yet to ascertain the former).The waiting time is terrible, turn around time is slow, extremely short staffed (3 waiters serving the entire floor). Food portions are minuscule, quality is substandard. The only saving grace is the dessert - red ruby coconut ice cream was GREAT. Then again, if you slather sugar on anything, the chances of it failing is low. Prices are not justifiable for the quality of food. Psh - NEXTTT.

0i4O_L15jSU_619aWPxfxw.text: Was here for dinner, wanting to try out their Thai food.. The restaurant was slightly above half filled.. Place seems pretty nice and promising.. What turned me off was the waiting time of the food.. Waited past 30 mins before asking one of the waiters to check on our food and he didn't even get back to us so we had to go to the manager before they decided to rush our orders out instantly.. Weird huh? Tom Yum soup was too sour, mangoes were too sour. Their greed curry and fried rice are acceptable, still edible.. What killed them was the service. Moreover there were lots of waiters running around so I doubt they were short handed as the restaurant wasn't even full of people. Won't be going back there anytime soon.

nX6nZrnkW3yFz5keLL4oVQ.text: The food is a combination of good and bad. The Pad Thai and yellow curry was very very good but the cashew chicken and soft shell crab salad were these deep fried monstrosities and the olive rice was actually average.Overall just another Thai place! The service was pretty average as well, getting the full order needed a couple of reminders. Tables which were vacated by other patrons lay uncleared forever until unless another group of customers required the table, pretty depressing actually for someone who had such tables in their line of sight..

AuHVV_KLx408TASv4nn5-g.text: My favorite Thai food in Singapore.  My wife is from Singapore and I look forward to having Bangkok jam every summer.  Mostly the food in Singapore is horrible but this place is a gem

iwyQ7osOpngf0l-VpOLbnQ.text: Paid $12.50 for a the curry pork that came with only 4 pieces of meat. 0/10 would not recommend! I will not be back again. Spent over 15 mins trying to get the staff's attention.
